With the wait however, it just is not worth it suddenly. Especially because I am from Southern California, there are a lot more ramen places that is just as good, if not better, than Monta Ramen. But for the Las Vegas area, this has been the best place to get my ramen fix. 

The broth is super fresh and clean, not filled with like oils and things like that. The meat is super soft, which just melts in your mouth. The noodles are just how I like them, RAMEN noodles. 

One bowl is enough to satisfy your hunger. 

Now to mention the wait - my family and I waited 50 minutes for ramen noodles. Factoring that in, it was not worth it. The waitress even let back people who "left" from the waiting list, and came back! That's not what a waiting list does, if a party leaves, they are off the list. The waitress would squeeze the party back in. That just lengthens the time I am waiting outside, especially since she did it for two 5 person parties before mine. 

They have another Monta in Vegas now. Maybe that one is worth trying out.

Found Monta in February and fell in love with it.  It's a good sign when there's a line and the majority of the people in line and inside are Japan Japanese.  You can't find tonkotsu ramen like this in Hawaii.  It reminded me of Japan.  In fact Monta surpassed some ramen that I've had in Japan (and I've had my share of ramen).  

The soup is perfect.  Milky pork bone flavor without being too salty or too fatty.

The noodles are tasty and cooked to perfection.  Kaedama (Noodle refill) available too.

The chashuu is the best I've had anywhere.  Blew away Menya Kissou in Tokyo, my previous fav.  Melts in your mouth.

The nita tamago wasn't that good.  Passed on it the second time.  Still cold when served which didn't go well with a hot bowl of noodles.  Hence the 4 stars.

Spent 2 of my 5 lunches here while in Vegas.

Ramen as it should be. But seating is limited and crowds are large. What you need to know is that there will be a line out the door if you arrive after 11:30 for lunch. Walk in and write your name on the list asap and then wait patiently. Be sure your whole party is there for seating.

6/5, got the pork belly bowl and my girlfriend got the ramen. best ramen she's had since japan and the pork belly bowl was delicious. also fast service and very reasonable, I could barely finish the pork belly bowl and it was less than $6, what a deal. you have to give this place a try
Best ramen in Vegas! Soup was thick and flavorful, noodles were not soft..and the egg yolk was soft and wet..the kind of stuff u would get from an authentic ramen shop in japan..highly recommended
Eaten here 3 times now. Always good. Food is great. Servers are friendly.  Best noodle/soup joint in las Vegas!

I had the Spicy tonkutsu ramen and it was okay, edible but I wouldn't rave about it. Broth was a little over salty and too thick for me, and they're pretty stingy with the broth. There was no option to choose how well you want the noodles to be cooked. Overall, while many said 20mins wait was worth it, I wouldn't agree. This place is overrated.
Love this place!  One of my favorite restaurants!  Tastes like you're in Okinawa/Japan.
Waited for an hour since we didn't luckily get to the first round and had to wait for the entire first round (like 20 people) to finish eating and exiting...

First time eating "fancy" ramen as opposed to the top ramen I'm used to at home lol. When I went it was very busy so we had to put our name down and waited about 20 minutes or so. 

We got seated at the bar and my friend recommended the tonkatsu ramen with nori and egg. The messed up on our order and thought we said corn instead of nori but it wasn't a big deal. The waitress brought our our nori in a separate bowl and only charged us for the corn which was 25 cents cheaper than the nori :) 

The ramen was so good! Not too salty and not to watery, just perfect. Also when you eat the pork it literally melts in your mouth. Staff was great also. I will definitely be coming back here!

We had to wait quite a while because this is a very small place, but it was worth it. We ordered Shoyu Ramen and Miso Ramen (x3), gyoza, and the kimchi fried rice. The kimchi fried rice was a total hit with our group, and everything else was good as well. The gyoza was nice and crispy. We will definitely be back but we will probably try to find out what their peak hours are so we don't have to wait as long next time.
Very quick!! And perfect Ramen. Actually I started to love Ramen while I tried it for the first time in my life here in this restaurant.

I can't believe it took us so long to find this place. If you like Ramen, this is the place to try. The menu is quite simple but the flavors or not. If there's one downside I have not been there yet when there's not a line waiting to enter. The restaurant only seats about 30 people, however the tables turn quickly. My favorite dish is the Ramen with black garlic.

I love coming here, especially on a rainy day.

It is very small and there is usually a wait, but eating here is such a quick process.  It won't be very long.

We usually sit at the counter in which you can watch them prepare your food.  I am that white girl that asks for a fork. :( Lol.  The menu is very small, but delicious.  I usually get the Miso Ramen and kim chee fried rice.  The pork is so good, it melts in your mouth.  My mouth is watering as I write this!

The staff is always welcoming & service is good.

Only thing is I wish they had dessert.
Pretty delicious.  Don't like the thin ramen noodles though.  It's not the normal chewy authentic ramen noodles.

Tried this place on a friend recommendation, we found it packed, and had to wait for about 30 minutes, which I thought was a good sign. We ordered the Kimchi fried rice and Tonkotsu ramen soup. The rice was good, the soup was frankly ok. What makes a noodle soup is obviously the quality of the noodles and the spice flavors of the broth, and I found the flavors to be somewhat lacking. Many restaurants are riding the sudden wave of the Ramen fashion, and only few are truly deserving, I let everyone make their own judgement.
If Naruto was a real person...then this place would be his number one stop in Vegas!

Best ramen spot in Vegas. The restaurant is small but that's what I like about it. The food is really good. I always get the miso ramen with thin noodles,corn and nitamago "soft boiled egg". Also the gyoza is really good. If your looking for a great local Asian spot this is for you.

This can definitely be on the list of hole in the wall places that are beyond excellent in food and service! This noodle house is very, very small and has a very limited amount of seating. I went in about an hour before closing, and were lucky in order to get a seat since it seemed very full according to the wait list from earlier.

Since I don't eat meat, I ordered the vegetarian option that isn't on the menu (you need to ask your server to special request this since not many people know unless you ask). Our server was very knowledgeable and lively with the words she used to describe the ingredients and taste of their dishes. Delicious, all the way! I only tried the vegetarian option, but I certainly will be back when I'm in the area to try all the other items.

Keep in mind this place IS very small, so you're best bet would be to probably swing in on the less busy nights or for lunch during weekdays. Hopefully they'll expand in the future, but I would highly recommend this place in the Chinatown area if you're looking for a slightly different menu other than the many pho places that are around that area.

The wait time for a table was long and the flavor fell short. The broth was too salty, and tasted like thick chicken noodle soup. The noodles they use are thin noodles and half way through eating my ramen, the noodles became mushy. I also had fried rice, very disappointed ... Bland and flavorless. The one good item I had was the Sapporo (although they forgot about it and I had to remind them TWICE). I would not return for a second bowl of ramen here.
Food...AMAZING...service and "rules" of party/seating/etc...meh

Hands down Monta has the best Japanese ramen in Las Vegas. I've tried my fair share of ramen places in Los Angeles and Vegas, and it's safe to say Monta beats everybody out of the park. The noodles are perfectly cooked every single time. The broth is perfectly filled with flavor but not too heavy at the same time. I love the thin noodles. I also love all their fried rice cooked to order and their gyoza appetizer. I'm not a huge fan of the 2 new ramen specials, but Monta never fails.
Everytime I crave for Ramen I go here. Never disappointing. Tastes sooo good! I just hope they would expand and have a bigger dining area. This is definitely one of my favorites.

Definitely yummy ramen and it comes out really fast, which is good because they only have 5 tables and maybe 10 seats at the bar, so they need to rotate people quickly. We went around 1pm on a Saturday and had to wait about 15 minutes for a seat. 

Ordered the Miso Ramen and the broth was really good, but a bit too salty for my taste, but still really good. The pork was really good, and the noodles were best towards the end of the meal because they had gotten softer after soaking in the juices. Initially they were more Al dente. 

Since this is my first visit to a ramen restaurant in las vegas, I'll probably try a different one the next time around so I have something to compare it to.

Affordable, close to authentic ramen. What more can you ask for?

Monta Ramen is a fairly small ramen shop, seating maybe about 25-35 including the ramen bar area, but like most yelpers are keen to point out, they do try to move guests along. My family of 4 came right at the peak of dinner 7pm and only had to wait for 20 minutes, not too bad if you ask me.

We started our meal off with a pork belly bowl which was just savory goodness. The pork drippings from the fat coated the each grain of rice and made it all savory, buttery, and utterly delicious. The slivers of red ginger also helped to cut the fattiness/greasy factor of this dish.

Next came our orders. We each ordered some variety of ramen, but noticed that only the miso ramen came with "traditional" ramen noodles. Everyone else received these thinner noodles...still good, but not what we expected. I added a pad of butter and corn to my dish which made it more complete in my opinion....I also appreciated the fact that add-on's here ranged from $0.50 to $1.50 as opposed to my regular $1.50 to $3.00 in the Bay Area (for the same two spoonfuls of corn in most cases). My only complaint, outside of the noodle-snafu, was that our ramen was delivered lukewarm at best. It was a little off-putting.

I read about this restaurant on Yelp and was very excited to find a good ramen place. 

As all the other Yelpers mentioned, it is VERY warm in the restaurant so be prepared! The whole restaurant only fits about 26 people but we were lucky we were the only customers.

I went with my boyfriend and I ordered the tonkatsu ramen w/ egg and he had the miso w/ corn, egg & extra chashu. Even in the heat I definitely enjoyed the ramen. The broth was very savory and delicious. The chashu was very soft and also very flavorful. I would definitely order the extra chashu next time we go there. I've never had corn in my ramen before (except for the american cuponoodles) but it added a nice crunch to the dish and sweetness.

The service was good but just be careful with your bill there. This was the first time we went there and they rang up 3 cokes instead of 2. After the transaction was completed she had corrected it by giving us cash back for the misrung item. After leaving the restaurant and being a day later, we came to realized the server charged his debit card TWICE for the meal as well. So not only did they rang up extra items on our tab but they charged the transaction TWICE.

Keep in mind that we were the only people in the restaurant as well so it wasn't like it was very busy. 

Overall I was happy with the meal, just will keep in mind to pay cash and triple check the tab from now on.
Best ramen house in Vegas...takes me away from Pho!!

Not sure where my old review went....but here's an update:

Can't say enough about this place! Its a must-have stop anytime I am in Vegas. I was teeter-tottering between Santouka in OC, but Monta has officialy taken the #1 spot by a slight edge. YES, BEST RAMEN HANDS DOWN!!!

You can't go wrong with any of the ramen broth choices. My choices are the Miso (ask for the spicy miso) or Tonkatsu (they had the spice tonkatsu as a special of the month). I like to add the egg, corn, seaweed, and if you don't mind clogging your arteries a bit more...add the butter (you won't regret it...so damn good and better!)

Other items:
Pork Belly Rice bowl: Its okay, it has a lot of ginger (in which I dislike)
Kimchi Fried Rice: If you got extra room or sharing, this is the rice plate you want to order!

And don't for get the Calpico!!!!

The place can get packed, so be patient....or test your luck here, you'll win regardless!

I don't know if I was just really hungry, but this ramen was delicious! There was a bit of a wait since I went on Sunday for lunch with a group of 15. But the servers were very nice and accommodating, and let us know our options of seating. The food didn't take too long, roughly about 10 minutes. The price was reasonable and I left happy. Plenty of parking in the plaza.

Wow! Best real ramen since ive been to japan. Worth a trip even if it's tiny and not easy to find,in the back of a strip mall lot. Get there early, they have about 8 tables and not a lot of space to stand and wait.

I don't live in Vegas but found this place on Yelp.  Excellent Ramen place...if you're from California, you probably been to Shin-Sen-Gumi.  This place I think is better than Shin...the waitresses here are very friendly and service is excellent.  I would recommend you try their pork ramen...

Great find here in vegas, the noodles were a little aldente however you can get the wavy thick ones that are really soft. The broth was really good strong and flavorful. I added spicy paste, it really didn't change the ramen much, besides that good service and the gyoza was really good.

We got seated pretty fast. There's a high turnover. We got our ramen pretty quick as well. We got the spicy tonkatsu ramen with added egg butter and corn. I loved the broth. The kimchi was pretty authentic. Service was 3.5/5, the host/server didn't seem friendly, but then again she was pretty swamped with multiple tasks (perhaps they need a little more help during busy weekends). Would most likely return and recommend.

Components of a good bowl of ramen:
1) perfectly cooked noodles (some prefer slightly chewy, but I like mine a little softer)
2) well-balanced, flavored broth
3) attentiveness of toppings 

Monta Ramen's Tonkotsu would have been THE PERFECT bowl, except it only passed 2 out of 3 of my criteria.
Great noodles, good chashu, but the tonkotsu broth was waaaay too greasy and rich. It got to the point that I had to dump water from my cup to dilute it down-- [gasp!] I know, what blasphemy! 

Had I known, I would've gone with the shoyu or miso.

This place was decent. I like the fatty tonkatsu broth with extra pork! But I have had better ramen before... The restaurant is very small so expect to wait a little... their side dishes are pretty good so get it as an appetizer to share with your friends

This is, hands down, the best ramen restaurant in Vegas, in my opinion.  

The dining area itself is rather small, and more often than not you'll have to wait awhile for a table (especially during lunch on weekdays, and on weekends).  I think it would be super difficult for them to accommodate to a party of more than 4 people.  

Their prices are very decent as well.  Everything is pretty much under $10.  Everything I have tried here tasted excellent.
Best ramen I had in a while. Try the one with chicken and pork brother, also the pork belly rice bowl, you can't go wrong W this 2 dish !

I've been here a couple times before hand, but lately it hasn't been what it was when it first opened. I went with my dad at my last visit. We both have the same taste in food so i thought he might be able to help me review this place. We ended up ordering 2 miso Ramen, as they contain the least amount of sodium, and we both were surprised at how they could end up making this one of the SALTEST broths we'd both ever tasted.. the worst part about it was it wasn't even ramen noodles.. it was the type of noodles they use in Chinese pan fried noodles..(thin egg noodles instead of wheat noodles)  which surprised both of us. I honestly wouldn't go back just because of this fact. The broths are just too darn salty...

After having ramen from the restaurant down the road,  I was quite disappointed in Monte Ramen.  

It was relatively easy to find...on the right side of Spring Mountain Road as you drive east. The parking lot is shared with other busy restaurants.  I could feel a slight breeze from the air conditioning which was really helpful since it was 100 degrees outside! 

The interior was small and dark. There were 5 tables and 9 counter seats. There were a few chairs for customers to wait for a table. Make sure you get your name on the clipboard! 

The gyoza was shocking. ..it looked pale and undercooked,  like it was just fried on one of its 3 sides.  The inside was bland and flat tasting. 

On the other hand,  the miso broth was really salty and the noodles were too soft. I didn't finish it.  The toppings of green onion, bamboo shoots & black fungus were room temperature as if they were hastily thrown on the top. 

I would only go back if the competition down the road was full and if there was no line.  If there was a line,  go to the other restaurants right next door!  Sorry...

Small hole in the wall place, worth searching for. Limited menu, awesome place if you're craving for ramen.  Small menu, very reasonable.  every time I've been there I had to wait about 15 min.worth the wait

This review is LONG overdue as I've been coming here since 2012 when a good friend took me with her. My favorite is the shoyu/tonkotsu ramen with extra pork and I also order the fried rice to go with it. Potstickers aren't bad either and they've got plenty of condiments to keep your food tasting great. Service is good, but fair warning; this place is ridiculously small. There's almost always a line outside so it's best to get there right when they open so you can get in and get out. It's got the reputation of being the BEST ramen in all of Las Vegas and in my opinion, it lives up to its name. Give them a try Yelpers!

I just have to review this place. I am a big fan of ramen and I have tried ramen from all the good places - norcal, socal and this place stands on its own!

The pork flavor ramen is so good, add a bit of garlic to it and you get the best tasting pork ramen you can get. I like it better than santa ramen @sanmateo.

The noodle itself is the thinner and softer kind you can find in socal and not the thicker kind you can find in norcal.

Got here about 15 minutes before opening so we waited in the car. There were some people waiting outside of the restaurant.

5 minutes before opening we decided to wait in line because more people came.

10 minutes after opening the place was packed!! I thought damn this place must be good!

I had the miso ramen and gyoza. Miso ramen was really good! Perfectly cooked ramen and a tasty broth. One of the best ramens I've had. On the table was pureed garlic and shredded ginger both not needed. Gyoza was slightly burnt and just okay.

Service was good. Prices are reasonable.

I was here to meet my friend and glad she did. This small place is known for their delicious ramen and for bargain. The ramen was so flavorful as well as the broth. My favorite part of the dish was the pork belly and egg.

We also ordered gyozas which I can't remember how it was like so it proves it wasn't anything special.

I got the Miso Ramen. The ramen was good, the prices are great, the wait was only 10 minutes on a Friday. However, we were shocked that they had extremely limited options for our vegetarian friend. She ended up paying too much for a small portion of fried rice, for which they would not substitute the pork (expensive) for a side of corn (dirt cheap). This is a small place, not good for groups larger than 4. I wasn't blown away by the meal or experience.

2nd time around in Vegas came for a late lunch and no wait!

So great because after the meal i would have been upset if i waited longer than 10 minutes to eat this meal

dont get me wrong it was good, but not mind blowing or something that I'd come back for.
I had the tonkatsu ramen with side of gyoza 

broth was good, but noodles were too thin for my liking. Plus the broth had this wierd porky taste like unclean or unorganic pork. (trust me I cook a lot and know the difference) Think pigs in a dirty straw pin taste...yee


Anyhooo it was fine to try it and $30 out the door for 2 pl wasnt bad, but the best ramen i've had is still in LA Tsujita 

Gyoza was good though- home made

ok to try once but wouldnt spend my $ there again. Sorry.

This is still my favorite spot for ramen. You just have to come early or later. You'll wait for a while if you come between 630p to 930p. 

Items ordered:
Gyoza- 
Always a winner, crispy and chewy wonton wrap with tasty meat fillings. Make your own dipping sauce with condiments on table.
Cold ramen with yuzu-
Great noodle chew with different varieties of veggies, egg and chashu pork dressed in yuzu dressing. Very refreshing
Shoyu tonkatsu-
A mix of both broth and those delicious noodles. The broth makes your lips stick, yum
Chashu bowl-
Exactly that thinly sliced chashu on top of rice
Pork belly bowl-
Sweet soy sauce cooked with the pork belly until super tender. 

I always recommend this place to everyone, it's a small spot that probably seats about 45 including the counter. Constantly busy and consistent with quality of their food.
Simple menu. Amazing food. Chill atmosphere. There's normally a 10-20 minute wait but it is worth it!

Was visiting for a few days, why oh why did I wait until my last day  shere?  Tonkatsu ramen was creamy and savory at the same time, delicious!  Gyoza was also memorable.

What I wish were not so memorable were the waitresses yelling the orders to the kitchen.  Please don't yell over my head, why don't you actually start shouting out the order to the kitchen when you have completed your short walk over there instead?

I used to love this place and somehow the BF one day didn't want to go. He gets that way. Either burns out or just finds the taste odd somehow. I didn't get it and have been thinking about a nice bowl of soup. 

So I convinced him to pleaaasseee come and eat something else than the soup.

I got the shoyu-tonkatsu and my taste has changed. It was just too salty for me now.  I took the noodles and didn't drink the broth.  I had a massive headache immediately after and drank a ton of water. Owies. Since I've gone and cut out processed foods I think I've become sensitive to high sodium. 

The cold noodle salad was still pretty good to me though and I took a bite of pork belly bowl which is still one of the yummiest things on rice.

I just can't see myself coming back very often unless I want some cold noodles.

The family visited Monta tonight. It was "A-OK" experience.

Tonkatsu soup way too greasy, we are talking about 1/4 inch of floating fat on top.  I have an high tolerance of fat, but this is too much.

Take my wallet and give me all your food!

This is the best ramen restaurant I've ever been to. My favorite is the tonkotsu shoyu. Their fried rice is also extremely delicious. I repeat, EXTREMELY DELICIOUS. I could eat here every single day if I could!

Trust me yelpers, it is worth it!

This is a small ramen shop in the back of a little plaza, there were people waiting outside before I got there (about 9:15pm on a Saturday night), and an even longer line by the time we ate and left (10:30pm). This is typical of ramen restaurants - the service was friendly and pretty quick (minus the waiting for a table part), but the reason for the 3-stars is the incredibly salty broth. I love ramen and have eaten at some of the best places in LA, and this just cannot compare. The noodles and toppings are fine, but the broth is so salty (and almost thick) that I couldn't even drink it. Perhaps it gets salter when it's later in the day, but I would not want to go back.

Ordered the MisoShoyu ramen which was pretty good but pretty salty.  Flavor is good and meat is fatty.  Noodles aren't as "bouncy" as daikokuya or santouka but for $7 in vegas a few minutes from the strip...non c'e male!
was an alright ramen place, lots of hype here

I love ramen and was looking for a place to try in Las Vegas. After catching a late show and not having had dinner prior to the show, I wanted something that would not be too heavy or filling. I searched on Yelp and tried Monta based on the positive Yelp reviews. The tonkatsu broth was very robust and flavorful, yet not too heavy. It was served with thin noodles and some greens, and I added corn which provided something sweet to compliment the saltiness of the broth. A definite member of my repeat list when back in Las Vegas.
Best ramen in the Las Vegas Valley! It is a very small place so there is always a wait but the wait is well worth it! Soup always hits the spot.

Honestly the BEST place for ramen in Vegas. Their restaurant is really small, given that it is basically a hole in the wall type of thing. So you're always looking at a wait time of atleast 10-20 minutes. But sometimes you'll get lucky and have no wait at all. Not gonna lie though. ITS TOTALLY WORTH THE WAIT. They're very inexpensive too.  I recommend their Miso Ramen with an add on of Nitamago, corn, and garlic. Sooooo good. And the pork that it comes with just melts in your mouth.  the only thing I hate about going to Monta, is the parking situation. Its such a popular and busy plaza because there are so many restaurants there, so everyone literally fights for parking.

I truly love this little gem of a Ramen House, with its limited seating and understated elegance.

Okay let be honest, there's only one dish, served three different ways, with a few small sides dishes and add-ons. But boy do they make that one dish well.

The place is usually pretty busy, and there are few seats to choose from. But a chair at the bar provides somewhat of a show as the cooks stack the bowls to warm them in preparation of the noodles which they shake free of their excess water with a particular flare.

You're in and out in no time and if you leave hungry, you probably didn't ask the waitresses for help in making your decision.

On a side note: it's not uncommon to find yourself sitting next to a beautiful and fascinating young woman - just don't blow it.

So far I've tried their miso and soy sauce based ramen and they were "wonderbar!"  On the menu, you have the option of adding corn, a hard boiled egg, and scallions to your ramen; so its almost like a make your own ramen type deal.  I loved the shoyu (i think thats what it was called) ramen. Amazing flavors to go along with the corn, egg, and onions I added to my ramen. 
The second time I came, I had the miso ramen which was good but I didn't expect the broth to be as thick as it was.  I also asked for extra noodles that I thought was already thrown into the soup but it actually came on the side.  For $2.50 extra, I had more than enough noodles and just saved the rest for later. 
As for the interior, its quite small but mimics the feel of how a real Japanese restaurant would be. Service is super nice and its in a good central location. So I'll be here a lot more often now that I've discover it. Thanks fellow Yelpers!!!

This is my first time and I am very satisfied all the dishs are fair amount and reasonable pricing specially the Pork Belly bowl is very good and fair amoumt with fair price.  and their ramen soup is the best      famous place but the line arent very long because service is so fast

Minus the wait, that is the only reason I couldn't give it a 5 stars. It has an awesome environment, consistent flavoring, great noodles and their side dishes and ramen extras are super legit. Always anticipate making a stop at Monta when I make my multiple business trips Las Vegas!
This place is by far my absolute favorite place to eat! They are cheap and tasty! Try the Kim chi! Or the spicy tonkatsu!

Being from the bay area, I didn't expect much going to a ramen place in Vegas. But the ramen crave is real. We went at around 10 and the place was almost full. Luckily we got a table right away. 
We got the black garlic oil ramen and the fried rice. The ramen was definitely up to the standards. The soup had such strong flavor without being too oily. The noodles were nice and chewy. The fried rice was good, but tasted much stronger compared to the ramen.
The best part, the noodles were about $9 with added egg and the fried rice was only $5+. So worth the money. 
The sitting through the terrible Vegas traffic is worth it.

Soooo good! Tiny little ramen shop. About 7 parties on the list in front of us but the wait wasn't too bad. Tried the Tonkotsu shoyu ramen and the miso ramen. The pork in the ramen was melt in your mouth good! Gyozas were generously filled & delicious. Tried their calamari-best I've ever had! Presentation was good. Efficient, friendly service. Huge parking lot and a good value. Loved this place!

All I got say is YUMMY!!! Highly recommended for anyone wanting to their ramen fix.  I had their tonkotsu shoyu ramen topped with egg and extra Chasyu.  For some reason, their chasyu is more pork belly than "Char Siu" that I normally recognize, however, delicious is delicious...Lost a star, however, b/c eggs are not included and considered extra cost.  

Beforeworn, for those who are coming with 4 or greater individuals.  The place is very small and only have ~four to five tables available for group seating.
Best Tonkatsu ramen in LV in my opinion.  Much better than Sora which was a disappointing experience.

Just went there today, long long line. Waited for 30 mins and had miso ramen. Not as good as I expected. Very salty.

Someone (Robert M) called me idiot coz my review or I just gave it two stars. Wonder, if he is related to this place.

My friend and I had a rough morning at the dayclubs on a Saturday, we were starving and figured we grab some ramen before heading back to our hotel. I love their simple menu, just exactly what we needed that afternoon. I went with the Miso Ramen and added Chashu Pork, Green Onion, and Nitamago (soft boiled egg). The broth was delicious, savory and well seasoned, toppings all hit the spot as well. The service was great and since we came at an off hour there was no wait at all. This was the perfect afternoon pick-me-up and a great spot for some quality ramen in Vegas.

I was first introduced to this place when my friends had asked if I wanted to try out the best ramen in Las Vegas.  At first I was hesitant seeing as I have had plenty of ramen in Vegas.  They are good but not what  I was expecting.  When he had said the name Monta, I was relieved to know that this was not a place I had previously eaten at which is surprising seeing as I have eaten at plenty of ramen places.

When pulling up into the lot you would have to look for it seeing as Monta is a pretty tiny place.  This is definitely one of those places where you would have to hear about.  One of those hole in the wall places.

Once you walk in you are greeted warmly by the staff and the cozy environment.  You can see the kitchen and the workers all hard at work trying to fill the mouths of its many customers.  One thing I have to say about this place, and I have eaten here many times, prepare to wait a bit for there is usually a line because of how delicious this place is.

Once seated there will be a small menu with now four types of ramen you can choose from.  A tonkotsu base ramen which is pork based, shoyu which is soy based, tonkotsu-shoyu which is a mix of the two, and miso which is bean paste based.  They also have side items which you can put into your ramen like corn and eggs which are a pretty much a must.  The portions are also very generous and you will get that good fill feeling.

I have personally eaten them all and can vouch for them all.  They are all so good.  Monta is like the In-N-Out of ramen.  They specialize in ramen and boy, do they deliver.  This is now one of the only ramen places I will go to eat.  A very cheap and delicious way to spend with friends or even eat at by yourself.  There are few places where I will eat by myself and this is for sure one of them.

Since my mother is from Japan, I have eaten a lot of ramen in my life. I also admit that I am pretty picky when it comes to good ramen. 

My husband and I finally decided to try Monta. We heard from a few friends that this was one of the best noodle houses in town. We stopped in on a Monday at around 12:30 pm. It was crowded, but we were able to get seated right away since a few parties left at the same time. The restaurant is really tiny. I saw the sign on the wall that said the seating capacity was only 26 people. We sat at the bar, which was kind of cool because I got to the see the employees preparing the ramen in their kitchen. 

Sadly, I was disappointed. I ordered the Shoyu Ramen. I'm not sure if we just came in on a bad day, but I thought the noodles were too hard and the broth didn't have much flavor at all. Also thought the Chasu was weird. It was easy to eat because it was sliced very thin, but I did not like that slimy ring of fat around it. My husband felt the same way about his Tonkatsu Ramen. 

Service was not the best either. The employees were slow with drink refills and they seemed to be more attentive to the larger parties in the restaurant. We waited a long time for our bill after eating.

Sorry, but this place just does not live up to all the hype. I would prefer having ramen across the street at Shuseki.

I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen. The meat is really tender and melts in your mouth. The broth is really rich and creamy, but too salty! I asked for them to make it with less salt and it was still really salty. 

I came on a Friday night and the wait wasn't bad. But I think I'll stick with Ramen Sora.
I love their ramen!! taste so fresh and something that you can't have in Las Vegas.

The ramen craze is now it seems. I have never been to a ramen place in vegas. Boy have I been missing out. Thanks to my girlfriend taking her friend out for her birthday I got to try Monta. This place is busy literally all day from what I hear. When we arrived for dinner it was no different. People are taking cabs to this place from the strip since they heard good thing's about it.

Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen is what I went with. It's a blend of pork and chicken broth. Basic toppings are green onions, two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots and kikurage. Of course me being super hungry I got extra pork, Nitamago(seasoned hard boiled egg) and extra noodles. So fresh and super good. We also got Gyoza (Handmade pan-fried pork and vegetable dumplings). They were flavorful.

This place is not super big but the food is worth the wait to get a table. 4 stars. I see more ramen in my future.

I must say this place is worth the wait time.  Once you get a seat and order your Tonkatsu ramen, you can get ready for a savoy meal that you can remember for a very long time.  The fried rice that we ordered came first and it had the most pleasant taste ever.  For a ramen place, their fried rice was beyond exceptional.  The texture of the rice was just perfection to the tongue, sauteed to a heavenly standard.  The taste just melting into your taste palette is nothing less then the gold standard.  Once the ramen arrived,  the smell of the broth elicited a mouth watering sensation.  The delicate slices of Tonkatsu just melting into your tongue once you start to chew it in your mouth.  The broth was also truly rare and exceptional.  This is definitely a experience worth the wait.  :)

This place has the best ramen in Vegas! The place is very tiny but I love sitting at the bar where you get a full view of what's going on in the kitchen. I like to order the miso ramen with golden corn. I'm no expert in miso but it's the most delicious I have ever had! The fried rice and gyoza are also really good too although sometimes the gyoza comes out stuck together and rip when you pull them apart. Otherwise the service has always been great and friendly, but winter time is the best to go because they have no air-conditioning!

So we have been wanting to try Monta since moving to Vegas 2 years ago.  So we decided to give them a try after a movie premier.   It was way past normal dinner time but there was still a line to get in.  It took 40 minutes before we got our table.  There was a dust storm that evening so waiting outside was pretty special.  
   The inside is small and not very impressive and gives you the feel of eat and get out soon as possible.   The service was pretty good despite being busy.  We ordered our ramen and a pork belly bowl.  The pork belly bowl with rice was pretty good.  The marinated Tender and tasty marinated pork was a hit with all of us.  
   The Ramen arrived and I got the Spicy Tonkotsu which when I mixed in the red spicy paste  made the broth nice and thick.  I really enjoyed the taste and devoured my ramen as if my life depended on it.  The broth had a great taste and the added on egg made it even better.  The daughter got the black garlic ramen which I didn't care for.  So the Spicy Tonkotsu is my recommendation as I am craving it as I write this review.  I do think my next visit will be to pick up as the wait can be crazy at times.
Prepare to stand in a line. Great base to their soup. Gotta try the spicy version and their pork belly rice!!!

Coming from the Venetian, I was blissfully leaving the tourist sin otherwise known as Grand Lux Cafe to stumble into the gritty strip mall that houses Monta, just right down the street.  In my love-hate relationship with Vegas, things like this definitely belonged to the first category.  

Two groups of very jovial Japanese business men occupied the cozy joint when we walked in.  They seemed right at home, joyfully exchanging conversations from across the restaurants to each other as well as the waitresses.  From the smiling eyes to the careless laughter, I make the speculation that they were tourists happy to have found Monta.  I've been there, that rare delight from finding a great Vietnamese restaurant somewhere completely unexpected.  

It was a frigid night.  Lips cracked from the desert air, my mouth greedily welcomed the steaming broth of the Tonkatsu Ramen, rich with pork bone flavor and complimented with smooth strings of fresh noodles.  Had it been warmer weather, I'd have opted for the Tonkatsu-Shoyu Ramen, a bit lighter with the mix-in of chicken-flavored Shoyu broth.  

I could do without the pricey upsell of add-ons, but I still highly recommend them, especially the soft-boiled egg, corn, and seaweed.  You may end up spending nearly 10 bucks on ramen, but it's still a better choice than anything at Grand Lux

Mentaiku bowl is a hell yes.  I'm not a huge fan of green onions, so I always ask for a light amount (which is still an awful lot).  Those gyoza's are also pretty tasty as well.  Did I mention that they are also hand-made in the restaurant?  I watched them make it on one of my previous visits where I forgot to check in.  Ramen wise, you can't go wrong.  Their tonkatsu shoryu ramen is my fave though :9
Love the simplicity of the menu and the broth was yum (a bit too much msg but definite yum).  I'll definitely be back on every visit to vegas!

Yes ramen after a drunken night is always good, mainly wanted the broth. My friend who lives in Vegas recommended this place as one of the better ramen places in Vegas while also informing me that it still won't be like the ones in LA haha. So sure why not?

The establishment is rather small, they do have bar seats and do try their best to make the place look like an authentic ramen place. The pricing seemed fair but the bowl sizes were a bit smaller than I was use to, but whatever, because when it came out it, the broth was still delicious to me. 

Like many other ramen places, the menu is simple, they have pictures and which broth you would like, I went with the miso and added an egg, it didn't take long to get here and it tasted great.

Finally got a chance to try this place..we came here a few weeks back and never for a chance to write my review.. So here I am, playing catch up! 

Anyway.. We've been hearing so many good things about this place.. So of course, it's bookmarked! I'm glad to say.. I tried it..& ehhh.. Well.. I've had better. Sorry fellow yelpers.. I took everyone's opinion and tried it when it came to my turn.. Just wasn't pleased.. The soup was weak.. Their pork was really soft though! Like melts in your mouth soft! So that's good.. I got their thick noodles.. & it was ok..my bf got thin noodles and he liked the thin ones better, my bf is crazy about this place though.. Then again he's crazy about every ramen place! Lol we also got the fried dumplings.. (Gyzo)? I forgot, but it tastes like any other friend dumplings I had.. I don't think it's anything special... Specially for that price.. Nope.. 

All in all, glad I got to try it.. Two bowls and one dumpling order came out to be $40 including tip and all add-on's in our ramen.. If you're ever in town.. Give it a try! 

The wait is pretty long though! Come in small groups! The place is tiny!

Food here is pretty solid.  I've had ramen in LA (which is much better back home, and I'm not trying to sound snobby, rather it's just something I can compare to), and the food here is a decent.  

Tonkotsu Ramen $(7) and +$2 for egg- slightly above average-The broth is pretty good.  It comes w/ 2 pieces of meat (which is detailed on the menu).  The pork base is pretty thick, so if you are into thick broths this is the place to go.  

My gripe is they don't give you complimentary egg w/ the broth, so you gotta pay $2 extra (which is pretty steep if you ask me).  I mean, who eats ramen w/o egg?  It's almost required!!!  I also would've preferred my egg to be a little more runny.  Part of the egg yoke should seep into the soup (but still retain it's shape).  The egg I got was slightly hard when I got it.

Pork belly rice ($5.50 for a large, $3.50 for small) - Average.  The pork belly is extremely sweet!  I think they use too much sauce or something. The sauce almost over-powers the taste of the meat.  I'd pass on this next time.

I was able to try my friends Takana fried rice and it's delicious.  10x better than the pork belly.

Tips:
-Not good for groups.  Restaurant is small, maybe seats 20 people inside.   Parties of 4 or larger might have trouble sitting.
-Egg isn't complimentary w/ the ramen, so you gotta spend $2 extra =(
-No garlic press available

My first impression of Monta Noodles is charred with the remembrance of being blatantly discriminated against. It was this past Saturday night and I actually expected to have to wait after reading the other reviews. My advice to anyone going when they're busy is to watch the list!! My party of 4 waited outside for about 40 minutes. After noticing people being seated that arrived after us we decided to go back inside the crowded little waiting area inside to look at the list. Our name was not crossed off but the 6 lines below my name were. Just then we watched as a table of 4 got up to leave and looked for the hostess to call us over. Instead she looked at a young asian man standing directly in front of me, to come over to the table. I said out loud "Wait we are next on the list!" It was futile as I was completely ignored. I then grabbed the list and walked over to the server/hostess that seated them and pointed out to her how we were obviously next to be seated since every name above mine was crossed out. She pulled the "I'm going to act like I don't speak English card" and mumbled about a mistake. She pointed to another table where the diners were paying their check and said we can sit there. Ugh! If my family wasn't so hungry after waiting for so long I would've walked out at that point. What bothered me the most is the fact that the hostess never even looked at the list before motioning for the other party to be seated. Would I have waited 2 hours to be seated had I not gone inside to inspect the situation? Now for the food...the regular fried rice was not very flavorful but had a nice meat to rice ratio. It was also on the greasy side which I like. The cod fish eggs over rice was not edible. It looked great but tasted really fishy and not fresh. I tried dousing it with chili oil and then soy sauce but nothing could quash the fishy smell. The kuro Ramen with black garlic oil was fantastic and is the only reason I'm giving this place 2 stars. It was very salty, which I love, and had 3-4 pieces of chasu. The broth was the star of the dish. The pork wasn't bad but a little bland, while the noodles and green onions seemed fresh and tasty. My family ordered gyoza, which they warn you will take 10 minutes to cook. I didn't try any, but the kiddos liked it. After our meal it took another 20 minutes to flag down a server to get our check and another 10 to wait for the check to be picked up. I won't be back, needless to say, but will say that the food is way better than the service.

Went there tonight with hubby and friend.  We ordered two tonkotsu ramen, one miso ramen, a side of chashu, an order of gyoza, and three beers on tap, total came out to $31.14 not bad.  

The gyoza was very tasty, chashu nice and tender, noodles were great, and the broth was alright nothing spectacular (better with the grated garlic they give you).   I like to put gyoza in my ramen (kinda like wonton mein or mandoo kook soo), there's something about dumplings in broth that makes me feel warm and fuzzy inside (my comfort food).  

It is hot in there and eating hot ramen does not help, my husband couldn't wait to get out of there.   Service was fast and friendly.  So far best ramen in Vegas.

I had the Kuro Ramen, DELICIOUS! Pork was perfect, the broth was flavorfull, I had asked for extra spring onions and added chili oil to it. SO GOOD, highly recommend! Will visit again on my next Vegas trip!

Nothing special, other than the fact that in addition to pork broth they also have chicken broth (Halal friendly!!) Though I've had better ramen, this will do the job when you're hungover. Prices are normal. 

Get there early, as the line is LONG. We got there 10 mins before it opened and still has to wait 30 minutes to be seated--the line was THAT long.
Really good ramen at cheap prices. It's worth the 5 minute drive away from the Strip to eat here. Just be warned they have limited seating. You may have to wait a while.

The gyoza and fried rice at this place is killer. The miso ramen a little salty for my liking and the noodles a little too soft. Besides that excellent ramen.  The service sometimes isnt that great, but its understandable because they are usually pretty busy
Best Romen in town but service is a little slow because of how busy they are with a tiny spot. Would definitely go back and it's worth the wait.

If I live here, I would be so fat from eating tonkatsu ramen everyday.  Their tanaka fried rice was delicious!  The noodles was great, not over cooked.  The ingredients were great.  The service was courteous and prompt.  Their is usually a line, but well worth the wait.

My family and I have been coming here for the last five years off and on. Sometimes once a month and there have been gaps as big as 9 months. We always have a pleasant experience and always have quality food. While there have been some slight inconsistencies over the years, we have almost always been happy with the food and service. This place is tiny and always busy. My favorites are the shoyu Ramen with corn, 2 eggs, and shredded green onion and also the fried rice. My kids adore this place and are always accommodated. The service is fast and the food is very reasonably priced. While I'm sure there are arguments for best Ramen in las vegas, monta is in the lead for me.

Tonkotsu ramen had a very rich and tasty broth.  Thin noodles were cooked well. Liked the pork topping but cold corn caused soup to get cold. The pork belly rice was tasty too.

Place is small so expect a wait.

First time here last night. The establishment is small, and there is a sign in sheet for seating. It was packed when I went in, and there were 3 parties waiting ahead of me in the tiny standing room waiting area.

It was hot and humid inside and understandably so. The cooks and front of the house staff were upbeat, energetic and friendly which made my evening enjoyable.

I ordered the Kuro ramen noodles with black garlic oil, and any concern of waiting in the heat subsided. I added in egg and butter, and the egg was an amazing addition.

I will definitely keep going back to explore the menu here.

During my last 3 visits here to MONTA I did not see even one Japanese person eating or waiting in the 2 hour long line. Do you know why it is that the Japanese community in LV has turned their back on MONTA? There are many reasons.....

I was confused. I was really confused. Why was I not a fan of MONTA? Every Chinese person kept telling me that MONTA was "the best". Every Korean woman kept telling me that it was "the best". Even their white husbands kept telling me that MONTA is "the best". My Mexican-American and Black foster kids kept telling me that Monta was "the best". Why is it that I didn't like it when everyone around me kept saying that it was the greatest? Am I just not Japanese enough to enjoy MONTA? My Dad is a 3rd generation Japanese-American and he did marry a Korean woman, so maybe that Korean blood in me erased my ability to determine what a good ramen is. But then I started noticing that all my friends and business partners who were born and raised in Japan kept insisting that MONTA was NOT "the best", In fact they thought it was "the worst". So I came to the conclusion that Japanese people just don't like MONTA like everyone else does. 

Personally, I think MONTA is  the California Roll of Ramen. It's a slightly Americanized variation, just like how the California Roll is an Americanized variation of traditional Maki. MONTA's ramen belongs to no true Japanese region.  It's made in America like Burgers and Fries. 

No one eats comfortably at MONTA. The place is extremely cramped, the chairs are very uncomfortable. The counter is made of that cheap plywood you find at discount furniture outlets on Maryland and Flamingo.  The bathroom is like 4 feet from the bar, and some guy always insists on taking a huge dump and leaving the door open. There is never any parking in the lot. Frequently, I just drive across the street to Shuseki(A Chinese-Japanese restaurant) where it's much more comfortable and the ramen is f*cking awesome.  MONTA is the most popular ramen-ya in Vegas, so why won't they move to a larger space? One of the wealthy Korean business owners who is a member of my Asian-American Activism agency informed me that Seoul Plaza(where Monta is located) has the cheapest rent in Chinatown.  The owner of MONTA is attempting to cut costs to maximize profits and that's why he won't leave Seoul Plaza.  Cheapness is the main reason! And Cheapness is also the reason why your bowl of ramen at MONTA is only half the size of the other 4 major Ramen-Ya's in LV. And Cheapness is why you have to pay extra for every little thing. You gotta pay extra for noodles, you gotta pay extra for the egg, you gotta pay extra for butter and corn! How cheap is that!!! If you get all the add ons, the bowl of ramen comes out to like $15.00. You can get the egg, extra charsu, extra noodles, 50% more broth, corn, butter, and garlic oil all included in the $8.00-$9.00 bowl of ramen at Fukumimi. The Deluxe Ramen at Sora also has everything included and it's only like $10.00 flat.

The f*cking hipsters! This is a major reason why the Japanese have left MONTA.  Hipsters are usually White people, but they think it's cool to hang out in latino areas or Chinatowns. I don't know why, but hipsters think it's "lame" being around other Whites. Unfortunately, they have chosen MONTA as their "COOL MINORITY HANGOUT SPOT!". As a Japanese-American, do I wanna sit with a bunch of guys with " David Lynch Eraserhead" haircuts who wear Geek-Sheek  glasses and talk about their feelings? Do I wanna sit with a 6 foot 4" man in a dress who is attempting to start a conversation with me about: Indie Rock, Indie Flicks,  Jesus(aka Obama), Apple Products, and how cool it is to wear sunglasses indoors?  My response= THAT'S IT! NO MORE!  I'M F*CKING OUT OF HERE! I'M GOING TO FUKUMIMI!

By the way... How f*cking long does it take for you guys to eat one bowl of ramen? While I'm on the waiting list for over 1 hour, I always notice how people finish their ramen after 15 minutes but just sit there and talk for another 45 minutes. This is the reason why we gotta wait so f*cking long to get a seat. 

MONTA has the worst Gyoza in LV. It tastes like the Chinese variation, and they all stick together like they are frozen(look at my pics). And they give you like 5 pieces for $5.00. That's like a dollar a piece!! Walk 2 minutes to Shuseki for a much better gyoza.

Why did my egg come from the Alley? They ran out of eggs during my last visit and then they ran into the alley and grabbed another box? Are the eggs just sitting out there in some kind of big jar?

A Japanese restaurant is supposed to have Kim-Uchi, not Kimchi. I saw with my own eyes, the cook here at MONTA going to Greenland to buy one of those giant glass jars of Korean Kimchi. At Fukumimi, Katsu-San makes his own Kim-Uchi which is slightly sweeter than Korean Kimchi. It's a true Japanese variation of a classic Korean dish.  

#$@!*$#%$ *%#!  F*CK I JUST HIT THAT 5001 WORD LIMIT

The best part about Monta Ramen is that it is completely customizable!  If you want to go with the bare essentials, then your bill is going to be the cheapest Ramen bill in Las Vegas.  Very good value!  But if you're like me and like a little (or sometimes a lot) more fixings, then you can add all that you'd like for additional prices!

Completely customizable and high quality ramen for a reasonable price!  The place is a little small, so I don't recommend big groups though.  Bring a friend or two and you should be just fine.
I miss you sooooo much Monta.  The ramen here in Florida is like well...terrible.  I would do just about anything to sip your broth, slurp your noodles, the pork, the egg, the everything.....me sad.

I was really excited to try this place when my wife said she heard about a new ramen joint that serves Hakata tonkotsu ramen.

The restaurant is minimalist with very little seating and is located next door to Raku. We generally don't sweat the decor, or lack thereof, as long as the food is good.

They offer shoyu, miso, and tonkotsu ramen and several other items on their menu. We ordered the tonkotsu, of course, which was $7 for a small-medium sized bowl. They used the thin white classic tonkotsu ramen noodles which were decent but lacked the elasticity or chewy "freshness factor" of other places we've tried. As my wife will attest to, I like my food salty and flavorful, but their broth was a bit too salty, even for me. It had an earthy shiitake mushroom flavor but was lacking in the porky flavor and richness of a good tonkotsu broth. Neither of us cared to slurp up any of the broth once we were done with the noodles. I found the two pieces of chashu were mediocre at best. They were somewhat tough and fatty and had this unusual ring of gelatin around the edges.

This place is arguably the best ramen place in Vegas that we have found so far. Unfortunately that also isn't saying very much. A mere year ago, both of us would probably have been more than satisfied with Monta. Damn you Ichiran for making ramen snobs out of us and forever raising our ramen bar! The search continues for better ramen in Vegas...
Delicious ramen!! The noodles are the perfect texture and the broth is rich and creamy!

Awesome Ramen place to eat. The Best Ramen in Las Vegas. Excellent Ramen noodles. I have tried every menu in each time I visit, so....delicious to the taste. The ingredients is fresh, for real...noodles, delicious soup base broth & large servings. Yes, truly recommend to everyone in Las Vegas. Add this to your bucket or check list when in Vegas. Till we meet again Monta Ramen.

You can't beat their quality, taste, and price! This is a MUST go to place for my husband and I whenever we go to Vegas. We will gladly pay the 30 can fare to get here. The pork belly literally melts in your mouth! So good!! Can't wait to go back!!!
Love the noodles.  Best ramen I've had.  The pork belly is also excellent.  You can't really go wrong.  Yes, it is small and yes there will be a line, but it is worth it.

ENVIRONMENT
Off the strip in Chinatown. This place is quaint with only about five tables and a bar, which means there's a slight wait. 

RAMEN
Tonkotsu Shoyu - comes with noodles and basic toppings such as pork chad by, black mushrooms, bamboo shoots and green onions. MAKE IT SPICY.

Not the best ramen I've had. I almost want to say it's bland and this place needs to offer more toppings.

Really good ramen. Fresh too! The wait could be long, it is a small location. The gyoza is good too! When you order to go, they give you the fresh noodles, broth, and toppings separately with instructions.

Lunch ... Order ramen , fried rice and pork bowl !! Taste are really sucks. Totally different like before. I used to go that shop almost 4 years already. Waitress are little bit bad attitude. I remember last two year ago , one lady was cooking noodle who is remember regular customer and very good attitude. When I get in shop she know already what I used to eat. No more that shop for any reason.

Very nice noodle house.  Good service, quaint layout, and the price can't be beat.

I'm struggling giving it another star because I noticed somethings in the 20 minutes I was there to make you go hmmmm.  You heard me 20 minutes to get in, order a shoyu ramen and asahi and get out.  Can't beat that for efficiency.

Menu is straight and to the point, if you are not here for Ramen, go somewhere else.  Broths are Tonkatsu, Shoyu, and Miso.  Shoyu is the base for me (kinda like vanilla ice cream).  Soup comes standard with a few thin slices of roast pork, green onions, bamboo shoots, and some seaweed.  The noodles were decent but not homemade, very stock machine made ramen.  I like my ramen al dente, these were not.  I did add the pat of butter for $.50 which was a nice addition, but totally over priced.

Sat at the bar so had full view of kitchen and how things were prepared.  Didn't like how the cooks did not sanitize very well, bare hands on food doesn't bother me, but when you grab an egg and some  pork slices, I'd like to see you wash them hands before moving on to the next order.  Also noticed their Kim Chee was out of a bottle, which they could have done a better job at concealing if they kept it towards the back.

If you are looking for a nice spot to get your ramen on, I would totally suggest going here.  Keep your party to 4 or less otherwise it would be a stretch to find seating for everyone.

So far this place has the best price for the minimum amount. Once you add in all the addition it will be around $11. Compare this place to Shoku Ramen which is down the street, it is very competitive. Again another ramen house with salty broth. Can I get a normal broth with just bone and vegetable taste then I add my own fish sauce and miso to my liking? The saltiness is still better than Shoku ramen, but then again it might be my bad luck at Shoku Ramen. 

Monta Ramen is pretty closed to my house. The combination of garnish, slice of belly pork, and broth is not fully met to the famous tonkotsu. But overall it was good. The service is fast. I get to pick thick or thin noodle. The decoration was earth tone which is easy to the eyes but not vibing like Las Vegas strip interior design. The kitchen is huge compare to the seating space. If they were to do a remodel again, they might want to calculate out the total space and give more space to the seatings. The last time I counted, this has less than 45 seats. I think they can push to the 50-60 if they redo the kitchen. The menu do not have a long list of items. Just broth, noodle pot, fryer and a few pots to boil. How much are storage spaces? I think there is a huge space for storing food to the decade. Not just 6 months supplies. Starbuck have the same total items but look at the reasonable kitchen size.

I usually go to the new location on Eastern/Serene, though I have gone to other one a well.  Consistent quality of the food.  The best ramen in town!  I love everything from the calamari, fried rice, karaage (fried chicken) and that crunchy spicy tuna appetizer.  Of course the ramen, don't forget to add extra chashu (pork). Yummy!  Prices are affordable too.

One of the most comforting meals of my life and one of only two places we repeated while in Vegas. I have never had creamy broth like what they have, but it will cure a hangover in five minutes flat. The noodles have just the right amount of chew. My fiance fell in love with their pork belly rice and I was lucky enough to receive the bright pink pickled ginger that he didn't want. It was the perfect accompaniment for that ultra-rich broth. And the gyozas are little pockets of steamed/crispy goodness. I just wish I hadn't been so full when I got them. 

The wait can be long, but it is well worth it and your food comes quickly once you are inside. The portions and prices are deceptive and you will end up with way too much food if you aren't careful. Overall, I highly recommend this place and suggest the cab ride if you're visiting on the Strip.

Yum yum yum, I love ramen, so of course I had to have it in Vegas!

Wait was not bad at all , 5 minutes, but we came in on a Monday night before my flight out, so that may have been why. I ordered the Kuro ramen (black garlic oil ramen) and it was possibly the best Kuro ramen I have had thus far. There is a restaurant that specializes in kuro ramen near my own home, but it does not compare to Monta's. 

The food came out pretty fast, which is always awesome. The garlic was incredibly flavorful and aromatic and just amazingly delicious. Chashu was also really nice and tender. My only qualm was that the broth was a little salty for my own liking. I had to add some ginger and sesame seeds to cut the saltiness a bit, but other than that it was very, very good. If I had access to Mona Ramen close to my own home, I would eat there so much it would definitely not be too good for my blood pressure.

Can't wait to come back and try their tonkatsu and miso ramen as well!
Best Ramen in Las Vegas. Then again there aren't many here. Love the miso ramen. I'm going to try the tonkatsu with the thicker noodles next time. I'm not a fine of the thinner ones.

Been to the restaurant area a few times but turned off by the wait. Well, the food must be good for people to get in lines, right? So I have my patience then finally put down my name once on the wait list. I was placed to the bar area pretty quickly. The ramen was below average. I don't see or taste anything special. Very lame, forgettable, salty ramen soup. Service was OK and even though it is not expensive, it's never worth the wait or the money.
Hands down, best ramen in town! Go try it now!!!

Loved it! Checked it out Friday around 7:30pm.   Small place, very busy but was able to accommodate a part of 7. Long wait but totally worth it.

Tonkotsu Ramen was delicious. Pork broth was buttery, thin noodles were fresh and pork was tender. Added an egg and corn which made my bowl complete!

Pork belly bowl was yummy and great for sharing. 

Although the place was packed and super busy, the 2 waitresses managed to get things done! They took our orders, refill drinks, take empty bowls and plates and clean up for the next party quickly and efficient.

Would love to come back next time we are in town!

If you are waiting and double checking reviews to confirm...Yes, its worth the wait. 

Don't let the small size of the place fool you. The ramen is some of the best I've ever tried and rivals Ippuddo in NYC (yes, I did just go there) except that they provide more generous portions and a cheaper price point here ++points

You write your name down on a sheet to the right of the door once you get in and wait. Came with the bf / party of 2 at 3 pm aka off hours between normal lunch and dinner times. There was still a wait but not too bad (maybe 15/20 minutes) and the line/list moved quick.

Only reason it gets 4 stars for now is uncertainty about the consistency of their quality and portion sizes since I've only been once.

Really nice place and worth it as long as you go there right when it opens of off hours.

This is my third visit to Monta but first time to review.  

1.  The lines - The place is typical for a Ramen shop, with limited space to eat and to wait, but it is worth it.  My suggestion is to go when it opens and it will be all good.

2.  The food -  Have had:
a.  Miso Ramen - Bean Paste Ramen, very tasty. noodles perfect.
b.  Shoyu Ramen - Soy Sauce flavored broth and a nice stand by.
c.  Tonkatsu Ramen - Pork Bone broth - my favorite.

All noodles are just right, al dente and the broth is not piping hot as I would expect, but tasty overall.  Perhaps they believe the western palate does not prefer the hot broth, but to me, it has to be piping hot to be perfect.  The soups have a perfect blend of roasted pork slices that are tender and tasty.

3.  Price - Very reasonable, approximately 7.00 depending if you put extra stuff in the noodles.

Check this place out.  you will not be disappointed.

Seriously, Im getting addicted to this place. Noodles are perfect, broth is always creamy and perfectly seasoned, sides are delicious. Service is quick and friendly. What more can I ask!!??

So far my favorite is Miso Ramen with Nitamago and Nori. Last time, I ordered the  Mini Mentaiko (with spicy cod row) and was blown away by how great everything tasted. 

One of the best meals under $10 in a city of great restaurants.

first time trying some japanie food and it is delicious. its a small plase only 26 seats , but we didnt wait long for seating. quick servise and food is ready for less than 5 mins. not fancy , but affordable and delicious.
Ramen done right!  The ramen here is incredible. Great service in this tiny little gem and fantastic ramen.  Search it out and make yourself Happy!

OMG!?!?!?!? Best Ramen you will ever have!?!? It is a VERY TINY restaurant and be prepared to wait at least 20 minutes, but it will be totally worth the wait!?!? It is amazing! The kimchi fried rice also amazing!?!?  this place!!!!
The food is always amazing here and the staff extremely friendly ! The best tonkatsu shoyu in town !

I went here on a monday for lunch.  The food is great.  My only complaint is that it is a small space and there is a wait, even on a Monday.  So you need to come right before it opens and get in line (there was a line of 15 people in front of the door at 11:15am, and the place opened at 11:30), otherwise, expect a wait to be seated.

If you love ramen, then you have to try this place. Easily comparable to authentic Downtown Los Angeles J-Town ramen. The menu is simple yet fulfilling and they have calpico soft drink too! Although a small place, its cozy and worth the wait in line. Ive been back twice in one day and its just as amazing as the first time. Highly recommended. I stop by every time I'm in Vegas..5 STARS!

Really good and authentic starting at the price of $6.95. You can add more ingredients to your ramen. I always get the tonkatsu ramen. I love their iced green tea. Their gyozas really good. The restaurant is cozy and and small. Their staff is really nice and attentive. An excellent hole in the wall gem.

Small restaurant that packs a hard punch to your taste-buds!
The ramen is super rich in flavor, which is good. The only thing I disliked about the ramen was the thickness of the broth. I'd like to have it a little more soupy.
I don't even know where to begin with the chashu. Whether it be with the ramen or the rice dish, just give it to me! They have perfected it to the point where it just melts in your mouth leaving you wanting more.

I only wish they have one in So Cal.  I had the Kuro and the broth is so rich and nothing I've tasted here. We have a lot of great ramen places here but nothing like Monta. The manager was also super nice and called us a cab. The wait was long but totally worth it.  The fried rice was also yummy! My new go to ramen spot when I'm in town.

Affordable and delicious! Sat at the bar area. It was interesting to watch them make the ramen over the counter. Smaller location but that doesn't bother me. I had the spicy miso ramen and the broth was just right. The only thing I added was an egg because what's ramen without egg? Amiright? But the portion was perfect for me. I also tried the gyoza. A good appetizer if you just want gyoza, but nothing special. I would come back!
The black garlic ramen soooo good. It's well worth the wait . The Gyoza and fried rice are great . Love this place .

A nice little hole-in-the-wall. I had the shoyu ramen without extra toppings and it was very good and filling.  I ended up taking the rest home.  The pork slices were very tasty and tender.  I'm not a fan of fat on meats but there wasn't much in the slices and the fat was very edible. When I get meat at some Vietnamese or Korean places, I get scared but this was great.

When you get there, you need to sign the guest list if the place is full (which it will be).  We had four parties in front of us but they were gone within 10-15 minutes.  We sat at the counter on hardwood stools which were not very comfortable.  The tables had padded chairs.  I'll be requesting a table next time.

I would definitely recommend Monta Noodle House.

We came here in the dead of summer last July for lunch and I'm happy to report that Monta serves up some pretty tasty ramen. A lot of the reviews warned against a queue but we were seated immediately and our food came just as quickly.  I quite enjoyed the tonkotsu ramen. The portions are on the smaller side and the broth was full of flavour but a wee bit too salty. I'll definitely be back here again!

We waited for about 30 minutes which was expected from the reviews on yelp. We got seated at the counter and ordered, small fried rice, small pork belly rice, gyoza, shoyu ramen & tonkotsu shoyu ramen. 
The gyoza was flavorful and good! 
The pork belly bowl was ok... But the fried rice and ramen was a complete disappointment! The soup is nothing but BLAND!!!!! :( no richness at all..
Will defiantly not be back

BEST RAMEN! The place is small but it is worth waiting and get seated. The broth is unexplainably delicious! This thus far is the best ramen place I've been to, comparable to the one we went to in Japan.

This is my new favorite place for ramen, and it's unfortunate that Monta is located so far away. Or is it? I say it's just another good reason to visit Vegas... again. I'm not a ramen expert, but I've had my fair share of ramen throughout LA and OC (though Daikokuya in LA is up there). Everyone has their own style of ramen, coming from different regions in Japan. My favorite just happens to be tonkatsu-style ramen.

After waiting about a half hour to get seated in this hole-in-the-wall, we were slurping away. The price of $6.95 per bowl is a steal, but if you want to add extras it can easily go up to $10+. I had the tonkatsu-shoyu, and I found the broth to be perfect. Deep, rich flavor, while not too heavy or salty. 

My particular bowl of ramen came with thin noodles, which were okay. I kept reaching over to steal some of my wife's shoyu bowl, which had the standard, curly-style ramen noodles. Those had a nice, al dente chew, and I just loved how it clinged onto the flavors from the broth. Of course, what did I do after I was finished with my bowl? I had to order an extra side of curly ramen noodles for $1.50. Well worth every penny.

The other part worth mentioning is the slices of pork in the ramen. I'm used to the thick, fatty slices of pork belly. At Monta, the pork is so thinly sliced that it just melts and falls apart as soon as you try to pick it up with chopsticks. It's a shame that you only get 2 slices with the bowl. Next time around, I'm ordering extra. 

I can just imagine my face dripping with sweat if I'm slurping down Monta ramen in 110+ Vegas heat in the summer. I was dripping with sweat in 70 degree winter weather in November! At any rate, it's definitely worth the short drive from the Strip, the sweat, and the wait to eat at Monta ramen.

Went there on a Friday night and it was super busy. But lucky for us we got seated right away at the bar. I had their spicy ramen w/ an egg, corn and green onion. Their broth was way too thick and they don't give you enough of it. All my noodles soaked it up before I could even finish. On the side the bf and I shared their kimchee fried rice and I didn't care for it either. Over all I was not impressed and I feel like this place was hyped a little too much. I will give this place another try but not anytime soon.
Will have to definitely check this place out again when in Vegas...that is all :)

Our last day in Las Vegas, We decided to go to Monta Ramen for lunch. Monta opened at  11:30am, and there is a line already!! We saw people lining up outside, after waiting for a little bit, my friend noticed there is a sign up sheet inside!!! Damn it!! They should leave the sign up outside! Oh, there is no sign saying Manto in front, but you can't miss it with the long line outside.

Anyways, after about almost 1 hour wait, we finally got seated at the bar ... which was fine, we get to look at the chefs.

Food! We ordered a Large Pork Belly Rice Bowl to share - the fatty pieces of pork were cooked perfectly, so tender, buttery, just goes perfect with rice! I really miss this!

Hubby ordered the basic Tonkotsu Ramen with egg added - broth is very bold and tense, and what I love the most is not overly salty!

I ordered the Kuro Ramen with egg added on the daily special board - black garlic oil ramen, I really love it. Egg was perfectly soft boiled, runny center. I do wish that it was thick noodles, this is just personal preference :)

My friend ordered Tonkotsu Ramen with egg and corn added - looks amazing!!

Very good and authentic Ramen place!

This Ramen spot has been my go to ever since I first heard about it in college. It's authentic, delicious, and comes out quickly after ordering. Can't go wrong there! 

However, because this place has that good of ramen, everyone is bound to end up here. When you walk in there is normally a line or a couple groups ahead of you. Be sure to write your name on the list and include the number of people in your party. They may not get to you for a while so just be patient. When you are seated, whether it be at the bar or at the table, you'll see why there is such a wait! 

PS. They have another location now on Eastern that serves the same ramen with a couple more appetizers than this Monta spot & the place is much larger. If you're not into waiting too much, I recommend heading to the Eastern location.

Next to my favorite Japanese restaurant (Raku) lies Monta, the best Japanese ramen house I've been to so far.

It's a small and busy restaurant, and I recommend that you time yourself wisely...otherwise, you'll be stuck waiting outside under the Las Vegas sun. 

The wait was over and my cousins and I were finally able to sit in the well air conditioned room. Let the ramen begin.

I ordered their special- cold noodle with the mushroom, tomatoes, pork. The words 'cold' and 'noodle' shouldn't be in the same sentence, I know...but this is different. It was a refreshing blend of meats and veggies for the hot weather.
My cousins ordered the pork belly bowl, which is served with rice. To attempt..to even try to get close on its description..it's like Yoshinoya but 100 times better!
The other cousin got the miso based soup with an additional corn. It's so creamy and filled with flavor. 

I rarely head to the strip for food, instead take on adventures to find the best Asian places here in the desert. 

4 stars for their awesome food. But if I could, I'll give them a 3 for the seating capacity. I just don't like waiting.

My second time trying Ramen noodles from a traditional Japanese ramen restaurant and I was not disappointed. Monta is located in the heart of Chinatown on Spring Mountain and although it is a divey, don't let that stop you from eating here. The noodles have great texture and the flavorful broth has lots of hidden flavors that will keep your tongue wanting more.

This place deserves 5 starts. Unfortunately I had to knock one down because it is a bit divey and cramped inside. Don't get me wrong, this is my kind of place. I'm willing to bump elbows to enjoy some good ramen. And I have to admit that does add to the charm, however, it can be an inconvenience specially during lunch hours. 

Nevertheless, really enjoyed this place and will become a regular.

I love this place. It's small so there's is usually a wait but everyone goes in and out.  It's very affordable and all the it's in the small venue are delicious.  Their fried rice is so tasty and gyozas are awesome. The ramen is creamy, tasteful, and their hot sauce is amazing.  My only suggestion is I wish they had other kinds of ramen like chicken or seafood. I do get tired of pork sometimes!

Everything about this place is amazing!!! Gyoza are delicious! Black garlic ramen is amazing!!! Pork belly bowl is a must!!!! Fried rice is also a must!!!  The service is amazing!! Very polite and fast, they do not mess around!!

Wow. Just wow.
One of my friends recommended this place. I was in the mood for something Asian/Spicy/Noodles since I'm a little under the weather.

When I walked in, I was shocked at how many people were crammed into this tiny tiny place. I opted to order takeout, so I would get it sooner, and I could use my waiting time to go next door for some milk tea(review for them will be next). They quoted me a 20 minute wait time, which was fine with me. 

I went next door, for boba, waited for my milk tea, and hung out outside for maybe two minutes, and he comes outside looking for me, looking worried that I had forgotten about my food or something. 

I get home, and am eating my Spicy Tonkatsu while writing this, and it is DELICIOUS. BY FAR BEST RAMEN EXPERIENCE I'VE HAD EVER!!!! 

Hopefully it'll help me feel better.

This is my favorite restaurant in Vegas. The ramen is incredible, the atmosphere is authentic and charming, and the people remember you (like Cheers, but saltier). Although the lines can get long, they turn over very quickly.
